Package algorithms.imageProcessing.transform

Class Rectification

  • java.lang.Object
    • algorithms.imageProcessing.transform.Rectification
  • public class Rectification
extends java.lang.Object
    given correspondences, pairs of points for the same objected projected into 2 images, methods in this class calculate transformations necessary to make two images parallel to the baseline between the camera optical centers and at the focal distance. Rectification makes the epipolar lines parallel and the epipoles at infinity. NOTE: if the epipoles are within the images, consider using Pollefeys, 2000 (not implemented here at this time). NOTE: alternatively, if have at least 7 points to create an epipolar mapping, can skip rectification and use stereo matching: "Stereo Processing by Semi-Global Matching and Mutual Information" by Hirschmuller 2008
    Author:
    nichole

      static Rectification.RectifiedPoints epipolar​(double[][] k1Intr, double[][] k2Intr, double[][] x1, double[][] x2)
      Rectify (i.e, warp) the left image correspondence points x1 and right image correspondence points x2 so that corresponding horizontal scanlines are epipolar lines.
      static Rectification.RectifiedPoints rectify​(double[][] x1, double[][] x2, double oX, double oY)
      implementation of epipolar rectification following algorithm 11.9 of Ma, Soatto, Kosecka,& Sastry (MASKS) "An Invitation to Computer Vision, From Images to Geometric Models".

    • Method Detail

      • epipolar

        public static Rectification.RectifiedPoints epipolar​(double[][] k1Intr,
                                                     double[][] k2Intr,
                                                     double[][] x1,
                                                     double[][] x2)
                                              throws no.uib.cipr.matrix.NotConvergedException
        Rectify (i.e, warp) the left image correspondence points x1 and right image correspondence points x2 so that corresponding horizontal scanlines are epipolar lines. NOTE that the method rectify() is preferred. 
         references:
 following the algorithm of Kitani lecture 13.1, class 16-385 Computer Vision,
         Carnegie Mellon University.
       
       there are many alternative approaches depending on datasets mentioned in
       Seliski 2010, "Computer Vision: Algorithms and Applications"
    
       Ma, Soatto, Kosecka,& Sastry 2012 "Invitation to Computer Vision, 
           From Images to Geometric Models",
       Chapter 11, Section 11.5.1
        Parameters:
        x1 - the image 1 set of correspondence points. format is 3 x N where N is the number of points.
        x2 - the image 2 set of correspondence points. format is 3 x N where N is the number of points.
        k1Intr - intrinsic parameters for camera 1
        k2Intr - intrinsic parameters for camera 2
        Returns:
        Throws:
        no.uib.cipr.matrix.NotConvergedException

      • rectify

        public static Rectification.RectifiedPoints rectify​(double[][] x1,
                                                    double[][] x2,
                                                    double oX,
                                                    double oY)
                                             throws java.security.NoSuchAlgorithmException,
                                                    no.uib.cipr.matrix.NotConvergedException
        implementation of epipolar rectification following algorithm 11.9 of Ma, Soatto, Kosecka,& Sastry (MASKS) "An Invitation to Computer Vision, From Images to Geometric Models". This is for un-calibrated cameras. If the images have a large range of depth in them or if the epipoles are inside the images, this algorithm can result in distortions. If one has camera intrinsic and extrinsic parameters, Ma et al. suggest use method of Fusiello et al. 1997 for Euclidean projection.
        Parameters:
        x1 - the image 1 set of correspondence points. format is 3 x N where N is the number of points. NOTE: since intrinsic parameters are not known, users of this method should presumably center the coordinates in some manner (e.g. subtract the image center or centroid of points) since internally an identity matrix is used for K.
        x2 - the image 2 set of correspondence points. format is 3 x N where N is the number of points. NOTE: since intrinsic parameters are not known, users of this method should presumably center the coordinates in some manner (e.g. subtract the image center or centroid of points).
        oX - camera optical center along x-axis
        oY - camera optical center along y-axis
        Returns:
        rectified points and the homography matrices used to transform them.
        Throws:
        java.security.NoSuchAlgorithmException
        no.uib.cipr.matrix.NotConvergedException
